alternatives.transcript: it's called sick building syndrome no the building doesn't get sick but the people who are in it do it's a problem that's spreading across the nation one special is on the

the topic was in town recently he is a certified industrial hygienist Jack Peterson welcome dr. Peterson welcome to Urban Insight where thank you I'm glad to be here you've told us about something called indicators of sick building syndrome what is sick building syndrome sick building syndrome has a collection of symptoms that people experience that when they think about it the along are attached by them to a building in which they spend a lot of time quite often it's an office building and quite often it

not it could be either your home for that matter sick building syndrome itself the symptomatology will vary depending on circumstances but we get mainly flu symptoms so upper respiratory tract irritation I irritation sometimes even dermatitis skin irritation on Sunday lunch and if people have been calling in sick and actually having these symptoms but can't really figure out what's wrong with them yeah that's right and it has to do with the environment

quite often the indoor environment yes it turns out that some of us are peculiarly sensitive to what's going on in the indoor environment and if the are that we are immersed in for quite a bit of Our Lives isn't good clean healthy are we get sick we respond with diseases that are ranging from minor annoyances to Frank disease that puts people in the hospital

depending upon the source these days everybody's talking about how unclean the areas and so what you're saying is pretty frightening how widespread is this problem how many people are affected by it there are all sorts of estimates they're all guesses because we don't really know we know first of all that the problem is worldwide it occurs everywhere that we are aware of I attended a conference in Stockholm last fall and

an International Conference on the subject and I found for instance that there is a almost an epidemic of Legionnaires disease in England at that at that time at any rate we know that in this country region airs disease affect somewhere between 50 and 100 thousand people a year and this is one of the in fact probably the most serious aspect of sick building syndrome that does it have anything to do with the fact that buildings are so well insulated and sealed off to keep

the outside element yes quite a lot to do with it because prior to the mid 70s we weren't even aware that such a thing existed and that's when we had the energy crunch if you were old enough to remember such things any rate that's that's when things started we started tightening up building so that we couldn't get fresh air into them at all because each cubic foot of that fresh air that comes in whether it comes in through a mechanical system or not ask

to be heated or cooled or humidified or dehumidified and filtered if it comes through a mechanical system and all this costs money and people were rather anxious in fact for commercial buildings to tighten them up and make them more energy efficient because they could make money by doing so and as a result we wound up with sick building syndrome in a lot of places now we know about the problem the question what can be done about most of the problem most of it 50%

of the time the problem is caused by inadequate ventilation solution ventilation yes either the amount of air outside air that's being brought in is not adequate or it isn't distributed properly the other half of the time there are all sorts of sources the National Institute for occupational safety and health a an arm of the federal government has investigated this and they found that all about 19 percent of the time the problem is from sources inside the building and 10% outside

the building and so forth I quite often the there are two interesting things about this well there are a lot of interesting things but to particularly coming to mind one is that most people seem to think that cigarette smoke or tobacco smoke in the air is the cause of sick building syndrome yes I know it's a symptom rather if there is too much tobacco smoke in the air this almost inevitably means that there's not enough outside air coming in to dilute all the other

that are in the air that will cause a problem with the tobacco smokers are not for someone smoking is getting to you that means that there's not enough ventilation that may well be the the thing that I notice when I walk into a building and I'm hit with a smell of tobacco smoke as I walk into the place I mean it's all over the place it's all throughout the building this means that we aren't diluting the indoor air with outside air as well as we should by a long shot now we can stop smoking

in the building perhaps and attempt to cure the problem that way but that doesn't let the other things that are present in the air get diluted properly either so we still wind up with a problem as exemplified by the headquarters of the Environmental Protection Agency that has had sick building syndrome problems for about the last year and a half and they haven't had smoking and that building for several years so it's one of these things the other part of this is that the most serious problems are

bacteria logical in nature that is exemplified as I mentioned by Legionnaires disease but we can also have things that are have various terms such as humidifier fever or swamp cooler fever all sorts of picturesque terms so does that mean like bacteria is easier to pass along from person to person when you have this no he doesn't the peculiar thing about that is that mostly diseases are not Airborne they are not passed along that way

way they're passed on by skin contact but if the bug that's causing the problem is Legionella that does cause problems by becoming airborne and we also have allergy problems that are caused many by molds and moves and bacteria shed their spores into the air and at these things happen to be growing in the ventilation system someplace got a real problem and sometimes that problem is an extremely serious one and one of the other

we can talk about is the fact that if the problem the sick building syndrome problem is not related to inadequate ventilation then the problem may be very serious and will probably require professional help to solve that don't call me are you frequently invited into buildings to sniff the air well I don't know how would you find frequently but yes I am I do some of this kind of diagnose what the problem is yeah it it requires

is much more than sniffing if if I can go into a place I find that the problem is not ventilation related and that takes care of 50% of the problems and they're pretty easy to solve generally but if it is not then it remake may require a heck of a lot of time effort and energy to find out what the source is and try to cure whatever that serves maybe a couple more things now one of the things you pointed out is not always a building it can be someone's home or resident my own home was a sick building

so happy that problem and what did you do well in my own home I all of a sudden awakened to the fact that my wife and my two German Shepherd dogs it had the sniffles for about six weeks Cole doesn't last six weeks and German Shepherds don't get the sniffles anyway and I started thinking back well what could have caused this six weeks ago and six weeks prior to that time we had had new carpeting installed in the living room and up the stairs and a hallway upstairs

we had two upholstered chairs delivered and we would had two Ottomans recovered now all of this fabric is probably treated with a urea formaldehyde resin in order to impart staying and wrinkle resistance and when that resin is new when the fabric is New and in fact all of the fabric that we have in the house was new then some of that formaldehyde makes off into the air and formaldehyde is just a really good eye and upper respiratory tract irritant

and it was this that was causing a problem so what I did was simply to open up the house about 10 minutes a day or a my wife do it I'm not home often enough to do such thing but any rate I asked her to do it open up the place wide open about 10 minutes a day now this is not long enough even in the winter time and this was in the winter to get the solid objects in the house cold even no matter how cold it is outdoor it's only Outdoors it's only the air that gets cold sounds like what my grandmother used to call airing out that that

that's absolutely correct and if you do this a few times a week you should cure sick building syndrome problems that are associated with your home and this kind of a source anyway one last thing we talked about high absenteeism at the workplace should managers and employers be cognizant aware of that you bet sick building syndrome will cause excessive absenteeism curing it no matter what it costs is almost

always and under almost all circumstances worth it because it costs an awful lot of money to have people away from work and if you can get them back to work by having a more healthful environment you're going to make money rather than spend it dr.
